ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic understanding of how to use a DAW. Introduction to the programming language SuperCollider. Introduction to making audio using physical hardware.
How to code in a music programming language, how to use digital audio workspaces, and how to listen to music in a technical manner.
How to produce on DAW, how to mix and master and how to use SuperCollider. Some work done with circuits and Arduino.
I have learned terminology and practical skills related to sound design, DAWs, algorithmic composition, and (briefly) circuits
Understanding of digital audio terms, audio engineering in a DAW, mixing and mastering, live-coding for music, basic electrical Arduino techniques.
Better technical understanding of sound, what makes a track sound good, how to navigate a basic DAW, sound synthesis, SuperCollider language, basic computer programming
Coding and music production.
An exciting mix of audio engineering, DAW usage and best practices, and programmatic music creation with SuperCollider 3!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was rather fast-paced but I thought that each unit really got to the crux of each software that we were working with. Each lesson felt very intentional and that was helpful.
Project-based and Prof. P always makes time to help his students.

One way to improve this class, I think, would be to have an example archive of older students' work (perhaps omitting some parts, so they don't give too much away) -- much of my learning was from imitating in-class or online examples anyway, and online help resources on Waveform and SuperCollider were often either sparse or inaccessible (I can't understand that sort of terminology without experience). I learned a lot from reading about my classmates' projects and wish I had seen them earlier.

Strengths were that it was very hands-on. No abstract theory, any work was done by you in the field, and live lectures showing these techniques helped. Weaknesses were mostly unavoidable due to the remote nature of the course, for instance, no live in-person debugging, and the electronics module was somewhat difficult over a screen, but professor's setup helped mitigate this.

Strengths: Dr. Petersen obviously truly cares about his students and tries his very best to make the learning environment both effective and interesting. Midway through the semester (this is probably unique to this Covid year), he made the grading system A-or-fail, which personally allowed me to focus simply on learning rather than going for a grade. This class is also a wonderful combination of science and art; you spend time learning the technical aspects of music/a programming language, but this knowledge is applied in whatever creative direction you want.
Weaknesses: Though this wasnt a fault of Dr. Petersens, some of the material/lectures could be a little dry, which made it hard to focus throughout the entire 1hr15min. Also, as someone with no programming experience, learning the SuperCollider language was EXTREMELY difficult and confusing. Prior coding experience was definitely necessary to make meaningful use out of the SuperCollider unit, since I felt like I was always trying to get even the basics down. This seemed to be a general consensus with students with little CS background.

This course can have some very boring moments. You have to learn the basics of music physics to understand music production, but I feel like they could be taught simultaneously and make more sense. You learn a lot of physics behind sounds without knowing where or how they will be applicable until later. Thus, you feel very lost in the first few weeks.
A big strength is coverage of material to an extent that will let you understand where to further your own studies if you wish to continue.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Of course I wish it were in person, but overall I thought this class adapted particularly well to COVID restrictions.

Overall engagement with the course was likely significantly less than it would be in-person. A strong effort was made to transition into the virtual format, personally working well, but it was hard overall to reach the engagement I'm sure is reached in person.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it is great introduction to music technology for people of any level.
I would! I learned so much more than I expected to and was completely taken out of my comfort zone.
Yes! You get familiar with a lot of music production skills, DAW and SuperCollider. Great class!
Yes, to anyone interested in music/terminology! Highly engaging, lots of useful information
If you are interested in learning the basics of electronic music production as I was, I would recommend this course.

Yes! I definitely enjoyed taking this class in my first year. It is both intellectually and artistically stimulating, and the workload is not overbearing (but procrastinating on projects can lead to a buildup of a lot of work).
If you like music production, yes. If you like coding, yes. If you like music production, but not coding, maybe. I loved the music production projects but I hated coding in Super Collider.
Yes! You will learn the basics of tools and engineering knowledge to electronic music production. A great intro course for a planned hobbyist or professional.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Physical aspect using Arduino over zoom
We were sent technology kits and did hands-on work, though instruction was still virtual.
Particularly, the combination of at-home assignments and lectures in which we would outline how to work on these assignments
virtual seminar
